title: Acer circinatum
text:
Acer circinatum, the vine maple, is a species of <a href="maple">maple</a> native to western <a href="North%20America">North America</a>, from southwest <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a> to northern <a href="California">California</a>, usually within of the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> coast, found along the <a href="Columbia%20Gorge">Columbia Gorge</a> and Coastal Forest. It belongs to the "Palmatum" group of maple trees native to <a href="East%20Asia">East Asia</a> with its closest relatives being the "<a href="Acer%20japonicum">Acer japonicum</a>" (Fullmoon Maple) and "<a href="Acer%20pseudosieboldianum">Acer pseudosieboldianum</a>" (Korean Maple). It can be difficult to distinguish from these species in cultivation. It is the only member of the "Palmatum" group that resides outside of <a href="Asia">Asia</a>.
It most commonly grows as a large <a href="shrub">shrub</a> growing to around tall, but it will occasionally form a small to medium-sized <a href="tree">tree</a>, exceptionally to tall. The shoots are slender and hairless. It typically grows in the under story below much taller <a href="forest">forest</a> trees, but can sometimes be found in open ground, and occurs at altitudes from sea level up to .
The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are opposite, and palmately lobed with 7 to 11 lobes, almost circular in outline, long and broad, and thinly hairy on the underside; the lobes are pointed and with coarsely toothed margins. The leaves turn bright yellow to orange-red in fall. The <a href="flower">flower</a>s are small, in diameter, with a dark red calyx and five short greenish-yellow petals; they are produced in open corymbs of 4 to 20 together in spring. The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> is a two-seeded <a href="Samara%20%28fruit%29">samara</a>, each <a href="seed">seed</a> in diameter, with a lateral wing long.
Vine maple trees can bend over easily. Sometimes, this can cause the top of the tree to grow into the ground and send out a new root system, creating a natural arch. This characteristic makes it the only maple capable of <a href="layering">layering</a>.
It is occasionally cultivated outside its native range as an <a href="ornamental%20tree">ornamental tree</a>, from <a href="Juneau%2C%20Alaska">Juneau, Alaska</a> and <a href="Ottawa">Ottawa</a>, <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a> to <a href="Huntsville%2C%20Alabama">Huntsville, Alabama</a>, and also in northwestern <a href="Europe">Europe</a>.
Uses.
Various birds and mammals eat the seeds of this species.
